image.altText: A three-letter logo "pwc" on a wall, with a head in shadow walking past beneath it.

items.synopsis: A parliamentary committee has described the actions of consulting firm PwC in monetising confidential federal government information as "a calculated breach of trust".

title.children: Parliamentary report finds PwC engaged in 'calculated breach of trust', but won't release list of staff involved in tax leaks

image.altText: A small submarine appearing to dive downwards into the ocean.

items.synopsis: The US Coast Guard says underwater noises have been detected by an aircraft in the search for the missing submersible.

title.children: US Coast Guard says underwater noises detected in search for missing submersible

image.altText: Murray Taulagi celebrates

items.synopsis: The Maroons can claim State of Origin series victory over New South Wales in Game II in front of a packed Lang Park in Brisbane. Follow all the updates in our live blog.

title.children: Maroons strike first after half time to extend lead in State of Origin Game II

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Maroons are on top of the Blues at every turn, but somehow only have a signifcant lead thanks to a very contentious second try. Queensland's kicking has been superb, their defence looks impenetrable, and Daly Cherry-Evans pulled off one of the greatest Origin tackles I've ever seen. The Blues will once again be ruing the decision to not to pick anyone on the bench who can play in the backs, because their attack to the left looks shot to pieces with Damien Cook playing centre for Tom Trbojevic. In saying that, they're attack right isn't too crash hot, and that's Stephen Crichton and Brian To'o, so the injuries aren't entirely to blame. They just look frazzled, especially on Queensland's line.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: HALF-TIME: Queensland Maroons 10-0 NSW Blues

props.alt: Queensland Maroons celebrate a State of Origin try.

children.content: The Maroons are on top of the Blues at every turn, but somehow only have a signifcant lead thanks to a very contentious second try.
Queensland's kicking has been superb, their defence looks impenetrable, and Daly Cherry-Evans pulled off one of the greatest Origin tackles I've ever seen.

The Blues will once again be ruing the decision to not to pick anyone on the bench who can play in the backs, because their attack to the left looks shot to pieces with Damien Cook playing centre for Tom Trbojevic.

In saying that, they're attack right isn't too crash hot, and that's Stephen Crichton and Brian To'o, so the injuries aren't entirely to blame. They just look frazzled, especially on Queensland's line.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Maroons break down the right as that man Daly Cherry-Evans once again latched onto a Pat Carrigan offload and made it to NSW's 20m line, then they spun it left and David Fifita popped a short ball to Hamiso Tabuai-Fidow who found Taulagi, who ran it in under the posts. But the pass from Fifita looked very forward. He was hit as he passed it, which made it look worse, but it was definitely forward. Alas, the try stands and Queensland leads 10-0 after 35 minutes .
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Murray Taulagi hits back for Queensland off almost certainly a forward pass

children.content: The Maroons break down the right as that man Daly Cherry-Evans once again latched onto a Pat Carrigan offload and made it to NSW's 20m line, then they spun it left and David Fifita popped a short ball to Hamiso Tabuai-Fidow who found Taulagi, who ran it in under the posts.
But the pass from Fifita looked very forward. He was hit as he passed it, which made it look worse, but it was definitely forward.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Stephen Crichton scooped up a chip on the right and broke free with no-one in front of him, but Queensland captain Daly Cherry-Evans somehow tracked him down 10 metres out. Amazing play by the skipper. And the Blues botch another play out to the left as Dmaien Cook is beamed by Jarome Luai's short ball. They're paying the price for not picking any real utilities yet again, just as happened when James Tedesco was KO'd in the 2020 decider.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 32' DCE pulls off a miracle try-saver

children.content: Stephen Crichton scooped up a chip on the right and broke free with no-one in front of him, but Queensland captain Daly Cherry-Evans somehow tracked him down 10 metres out. Amazing play by the skipper.

And the Blues botch another play out to the left as Dmaien Cook is beamed by Jarome Luai's short ball. They're paying the price for not picking any real utilities yet again, just as happened when James Tedesco was KO'd in the 2020 decider.

image.altText: A policeman carries a tub of valuables in one arm in front of a school

items.synopsis: Parents have been asked to pick up their preschoolers after seven classrooms were rendered unusable in a suburban primary school vandalism attack.

title.children: Darwin primary school trashed, students sent home as Northern Territory faces $800k school break-in bill

image.altText: A train which has been smashed and derailed sitting across train tracks

items.synopsis: Four people were injured after a freight train and a truck collided at a railway level crossing in the Katherine suburb of Cossack last week, with authorities still investigating the cause.

title.children: Investigations continue into Katherine collision involving freight train and truck

image.altText: A man in a suit with an NDIS sign

items.synopsis: NDIS participants will have more control over the length of their plans within the next 12 months, according to the Minister for the National Disability Insurance Scheme Bill Shorten.

title.children: NDIS minister vows to crack down on prices, offers participants greater flexibility

image.altText: Small local newspapers have been disappearing across Australia.

items.synopsis: The new publication will mark the return of an Alice Springs-based newspaper after the Centralian Advocate ceased printing during the COVID-19 pandemic.

title.children: New Alice Springs local newspaper to launch three years after News Corp pulled print edition

image.altText: Young kids at the Tennant Creek Show

items.synopsis: The rural Northern Territory show is brought back from the brink with the Barkly Regional Council and NT government teaming up to ensure it can go ahead.

title.children: Tennant Creek Show 2023 saved after cancellation announcement

image.altText: An Indigenous woman speaks with a middle-aged white man in the outback.

items.synopsis: More than 80 judges from the Federal Circuit and Family Court have toured remote Aboriginal communities in the NT to listen, learn and break down barriers.

title.children: Family Court judges take NT outback trip in bid to break down fear in Indigenous communities

image.altText: A frozen bubble, with icicle underneath it.

items.synopsis: Temperatures across NSW plummeted overnight. It's now been confirmed many towns have experienced their coldest June morning on record.

title.children: New records set for coldest June morning after freezing conditions hit nation's south-east overnight

image.altText: A kangaroo stands in front of two soccer boots, one made by Nike and the other by Puma.

items.synopsis: Commercial kangaroo shooters are regulated under a national code that's supposed to protect animal welfare, but activists say what happens in rural Australia at night can be in breach of it, putting the industry under threat.

title.children: Why big brands in the US are ditching kangaroo leather

image.altText: Marnus Labuschagne jumps up close to the pitch as Jonny Bairstow completes a sweep shot

items.synopsis: Australia and England are penalised two World Test Championship points each and fined 40 per cent of their match fees after being found guilty of maintaining slow over rates during the first Ashes test, the International Cricket Council (ICC) said.

title.children: Australia and England fined for low over rate in first Ashes Test, Labuschagne loses top Test batter spot to Root

image.altText: People holding up alcoholic cocktails

items.synopsis: Going alcohol-free can spare you a hangover and save money — unless your new drink of choice is the zero-free version of certain high-profile tipples, writes Cameron Shackell.

title.children: Why are non-alcoholic drinks so expensive when they have less tax and no booze?

image.altText: A picture of a sign which says Titanic survey expedition.

items.synopsis: As the search continues for the missing Titan submersible, questions are being raised around the vessel's safety and what could have possibly gone wrong.

title.children: Was the Titan safe? Questions raised over what went wrong with the missing submersible

image.altText: A middle-aged man in jeans and a jacket sits in a chair and smiles. In front is a table with Titanic Expedition written on it

items.synopsis: A renowned Titanic expert, a world-record-holding adventurer, two members of one of Pakistan's wealthiest families and the CEO of the company leading an expedition to the world's most famous shipwreck are facing critical danger aboard a small submersible that has gone missing in the Atlantic Ocean.

title.children: A Titanic expert, an adventurer, a father and his son and a CEO: These are the people on the missing submersible

image.altText: Joe Biden sits at a desk while Xi Jinping can be seen on a TV screen.

items.synopsis: US President Joe Biden refers to Xi Jinping as a "dictator" during a fundraiser in California, also saying his Chinese counterpart was embarrassed when a balloon "full of spy equipment" blew into United States airspace earlier this year.

title.children: Biden calls Xi a dictator, claims he was embarrassed by 'spy' balloon incident

image.altText: A WOMAN IN A PINK SHIRT COMFORTS AND EMOTIONAL WOMAN IN A BLACK SHIRT

items.synopsis: Honduras president says the attacks were planned by street gangs who wield power inside the country's prison system.

title.children: More than 40 women dead, most burnt to death in Honduras prison riot

image.altText: Smoke rises over buildings in Khartoum, Sudan

items.synopsis: A 72-hour ceasefire ends in Sudan's capital after heavy clashes break out between rival military factions.

title.children: Fighting surges in Sudan's capital as three-day ceasefire expires

image.altText: A composite image showing a young man, a woman and an older man.

items.synopsis: Confidentiality laws have long kept the plight of people whose finances are controlled by the state hidden from view, but there are growing calls for the agencies these vulnerable people depend on to be subjected to greater scrutiny.

title.children: Can public trustees' controversial business model withstand the spotlight?

image.altText: The Ford sign outside the company's Melbourne head office

items.synopsis: Ford's planned job cuts will amount to about 22 per cent of its workforce in Australia, with the majority impacting Geelong workers in product development and design roles.

title.children: Ford set to axe 400 jobs, with Geelong workers facing biggest cuts

image.altText: Ice

items.synopsis: A Tasmanian inquiry hears disturbing accounts of children being injected and given ice by parents wanting them to commit crimes.

title.children: 'You poor little thing': Parents injecting kids with ice to commit crimes, inquiry hears

image.altText: Transmission towers rise into the sky over some buildings and trees

items.synopsis: Regional communities want to know whether powerlines connecting renewables to the grid to power the state's transition can go underground — but the answer may not be so simple.

title.children: Inquiry to probe undergrounding of thousands of kilometres of renewable energy powerlines

image.altText: an elderly woman looking at the camera

items.synopsis: At the time of the incident at the Yallambee Lodge nursing home last month, questions were raised as to why the original media release from NSW Police omitted the word "taser".

title.children: 'Really questions her competence': NSW minister under fire over claims of cover-up over tasering of 95yo

image.altText: Sydney gay hate murders

items.synopsis: Legal correspondence about an inquiry into gay hate crimes reveals NSW Police provided material more than a year late and seemingly found old crime scene photographs "by chance".

title.children: Police found crime scene photos 'by chance' 40 years after toilet block death, letters show

image.altText: A woman's hand on her bare feet next to a child's hand on a toy.

items.synopsis: From June 30, vulnerable NSW communities are losing legal outreach support for women experiencing domestic and sexual violence.

title.children: 'Critical' NSW domestic violence outreach solicitor to cease operating after funding pulled

image.altText: A man runs along a dirt road.

items.synopsis: Phil Gore ran from Saturday morning until this afternoon to claim the Backyard Ultra title.

title.children: Australian sets world record after running 685km in four days on a cattle farm

image.altText: Yunupingu with Gumatj children at Garma in 2019.

items.synopsis: Late Gumatj clan leader Yunupingu won a historic legal battle that could have significant implications for compensation claims across Australia. The Commonwealth is now appealing.

title.children: Commonwealth lodges High Court challenge to landmark $700 million native title compensation claim

image.altText: Lea Russ lying in a hospital bed wearing a blue surgical mask, with her arm hooked up to an IV.

items.synopsis: Patients who need to see a GP urgently are increasingly waiting more than 24 hours to be seen. But they may not know that general practices are meant to offer emergency bookings.

title.children: Getting an urgent GP appointment can be hard, but a little-known rule means it shouldn't be

image.altText: woman in scrubs stands cross armed

items.synopsis: A rushed takeover sale could leave a regional Victoria community without any doctors due to "clinical governance" concerns.

title.children: Vic town's only GPs vow to leave if sale of health service proceeds

image.altText: A large sign reading Port Pirie Regional Health Service outside a collection of buildings.

items.synopsis: A nursing union calls for 24/7 security guards after five medical staff were injured by a man suffering a psychotic episode at a South Australian hospital.

title.children: Two nurses and three doctors attacked by patient in 'terrifying incident' at regional hospital

image.altText: Woman with long dark hair in a black tee shirt.

items.synopsis: A health service executive says young kids are getting the devices from home, amid calls for more education about the dangers of the habit.

title.children: Health forum hears four-year-old Indigenous children are vaping as addiction rates rise

image.altText: People protest outside a building

items.synopsis: The announcement follows a similar decision by US aluminium giant Alcoa, which vowed not to mine an 8,400-hectare zone around Dwellingup that environmentalists call "greenwashing".

title.children: Rio Tinto bows to community pressure, withdraws mining application for south-west forest

image.altText: Nicola Gobbo gazing into the distance with her arms folded

items.synopsis: The special investigator appointed to build criminal cases against those involved in the Lawyer X scandal has attacked the director of public prosecutions for refusing to approve criminal charges against them.

title.children: Former High Court judge asked to assess potential Lawyer X charges lashes the state's chief prosecutor

image.altText: Three grey nurse sharks, near the surface of the water.

items.synopsis: The group of grey nurse sharks are attracting attention with their visits close to shore on the NSW Mid North Coast, but their arrival has come with a warning.

title.children: Onlookers delighted as endangered sharks congregate near coastal breakwall
